The Buddha said:
What is the taste of desire?
It is the pleasure and joy that arise from the five sense pleasures. This is the ultimate taste of desire, there is nothing beyond it, but the harm is much greater.
What is the harm of desire?

A son of a good family, according to his skills and arts, makes a living for himself. He may engage in farming, engage in business, study writing, understand mathematics, know how to count, be skilled in carving seals, write literary works, create calligraphy, understand scriptures, become a brave general, or serve the king.
When it's cold, he's cold; when it's hot, he's hot. He suffers from hunger and thirst, fatigue, and mosquito and gadfly bites. He engages in such work seeking to earn money.

If that son of a good family, through such skillful means, such conduct, and such seeking, does not obtain money and wealth, he will then give rise to sorrow, suffering, grief, and distress. His mind becomes deluded and he says:
'In vain did I work and suffer, with no fruit to my seeking.'
If that son of a good family, through such skillful means, such conduct, and such seeking, obtains money and wealth, he will then cherish it, guard it, and keep it hidden.
Why is it so?
'I do not want my wealth to be taken away by the king, robbed by thieves, burned by fire, rot, lost, or become unproductive, or to be wasted in various ways.'

If their wealth is taken away by the king, robbed by thieves, burned by fire, rot, or lost, they will give rise to sorrow, suffering, unhappiness, and distress, and their minds will become deluded, saying:
'What was loved and cherished for a long time has now been lost.'
This is called the present suffering aggregate, which arises from desire, is conditioned by desire, and has desire as its basis.

Furthermore, because of desire, conditioned by desire, with desire as the basis, sentient beings argue with their children, children argue with their parents, and there are disputes among fathers, sons, brothers, sisters, and relatives.

Having thus quarreled and fought with each other, the mother speaks ill of the son, the son speaks ill of the mother, and the father, brothers, sisters, and relatives speak ill of each other, let alone other people.
This is called the present suffering aggregate, which arises from desire, is conditioned by desire, and has desire as its basis.

Furthermore, because beings, due to desire, with desire as the basis, kings quarrel with kings, brahmins quarrel with brahmins, householders quarrel with householders, commoners quarrel with commoners, countries quarrel with countries. Because of the mutual hatred arising from the quarrels, they harm each other with various weapons, either by fistfights, throwing stones, or hitting with sticks and swords. When they fight, some die, some are frightened, and they experience extremely heavy suffering. This is called the present suffering aggregate, which arises from desire, is conditioned by desire, and has desire as its basis.

Furthermore, because beings are caused by desire, have desire as a condition, and take desire as a basis, they put on armor and robes, carry spears and bows and arrows, or hold swords and shields, and enter into battle formations. They may fight with elephants, horses, chariots, or infantry, or with men and women.

When they fight, they may die or be terrified, and experience extremely heavy suffering. This is called the present suffering aggregate, caused by desire, having desire as a condition, and taking desire as a basis.

Furthermore, because beings are caused by desire, have desire as a condition, and take desire as a basis, they put on armor and robes, carry spears and bows and arrows, or hold swords and shields, and go to conquer other countries, attack cities and break through strongholds, fighting each other in battle. They beat drums and blow horns, shouting loudly, or strike with hammers, spears, or sharp wheels, or shoot arrows, or throw down rocks, or use large crossbows, or sprinkle molten copper and iron pellets.

When they fight, some die, some are frightened, and they experience extremely heavy suffering. This is called the present suffering aggregate, which is caused by desire, has desire as its source, and is rooted in desire.

Furthermore, because beings are caused by desire, have desire as their source, and are rooted in desire, they put on armor, wear robes, carry spears and arrows, or hold swords and shields, and enter villages, towns, countries, and cities to dig through walls, open up storehouses, rob and steal property, block the king's roads, or go to other alleys to destroy villages, harm towns, annihilate countries, and raze cities.
In the midst of this, they may be captured by the king's men, who will torture them in various ways, cutting off their hands, cutting off their feet, or
cutting off both their hands and feet, cutting off their ears, cutting off their noses, or cutting off both their ears and nose. They may be cut to pieces, their
beards pulled out, their hair pulled out, or their beards and hair pulled out. They may be put in a cage and wrapped in cloth to be burned, or
buried in sand, wrapped in grass, and burned with fire, or put in an iron donkey's belly, or put in an iron pig's mouth.
Or placed in the mouth of an iron tiger to burn, or placed in a copper cauldron, or placed in an iron cauldron
to cook, or cut into pieces, or pierced with sharp forks, or hooked with iron hooks, or lying on an iron
bed and poured with boiling oil, or sitting in an iron mortar and pounded with an iron pestle, or bitten by dragons and snakes,
or whipped with whips, or beaten with sticks, or beaten with clubs, or impaled alive on a high pole,
or decapitated.

There, either dead or frightened, they experience extremely heavy suffering. This is called the present suffering aggregate, which is caused by desire, has desire as its source, and arises from desire.

Furthermore, because sentient beings are caused by desire, have desire as their source, and arise from desire, they engage in evil bodily actions, evil verbal and mental actions. Later, when they are sick and lying in bed, or sitting or lying on the ground, suffering afflicts their bodies, and they experience extremely heavy suffering that is not pleasant or enjoyable.

If they have bodily misconduct, verbal misconduct, and mental misconduct, when they are about to die, they are covered by what is in front of them, just like when the sun is about to set behind a large mountain, its shadow covers the ground.
In the same way, if they have bodily misconduct, verbal misconduct, and mental misconduct, they are covered by what is in front of them. They think:
'My previous misconduct covers me. I did not do meritorious deeds, but did many evil deeds.

If there were a person who did evil and violence, only creating offenses, not doing merit or practicing good, having no fear, no refuge, and no place to return to, wherever they were born, I would definitely be born there.'

From this, there is regret. One who regrets dies unskillfully, and dies without merit. This is called the present suffering aggregate, caused by desire, conditioned by desire, with desire as its source.

Furthermore, beings, because of desire, on account of desire, with desire as the basis, engage in misconduct with the body, speech, and mind. Because of engaging in misconduct with the body, speech, and mind, after the breaking up of the body, following death, they certainly go to a bad realm of existence, to the hells. This is called the future suffering and distress that arises from desire, on account of desire, with desire as the basis. This is called the danger of desire.
What is the escape from desire?
If one cuts off desire, abandons desire, eliminates desire, and transcends desire, this is called the escape from desire.

If there are renunciants and brahmins who do not truly know the enjoyment, danger, and escape regarding desire, they will not be able to cut off their own desire, let alone be able to cut off the desire of others.

If there are renunciants and brahmins who truly know the enjoyment, danger, and escape regarding desire, they will be able to cut off their own desire and also be able to cut off the desire of others.

If it is a ká¹£atriya girl, a brahmin girl, a householder girl, or a worker girl, at the age of fourteen or fifteen, at that time, her beautiful form is the most wonderful.

If one sees that beautiful woman later, extremely old, with white hair and falling teeth, hunched back and crooked legs, walking with a cane, her prime youth fading away, her life coming to an end, her body shaking, her faculties decaying, what do you think?

He replied:

What is the gratification in perception?

A monk, detached from sensual pleasures, detached from unwholesome states, enters and dwells in the first absorption, which is accompanied by thought and examination, with joy and happiness born of detachment. At that time he does not think of harming himself, nor does he think of harming others, nor does he think of harming both. This is called the gratification in perception.
Why is it so?
Because not thinking of harming oneself is the attainment of this happiness, this is called the gratification in perception.
What is the danger in perception?
Perception is an impermanent phenomenon, a suffering phenomenon, and a cessation phenomenon. This is called the danger in perception.
What is the escape in perception?
If one cuts off perception, abandons perception, extinguishes perception, and transcends perception, this is called the transcendence of perception.

If there are ascetics and brahmins who do not truly know the enjoyment, danger, and escape of perception, they will never be able to cut off their own perception, let alone be able to cut off the perception of others.
If there are ascetics and brahmins who truly know the enjoyment, danger, and escape of perception, they will be able to eliminate it themselves and also be able to cut off the perception of others.
